description: Anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies act through Fcγ-receptor (FcγR) signalling to promote repolarisation of proinflammatory intestinal macrophages.
Anti-TNF therapy increased macrophage IL-10 production in an FcγR-dependent manner.
IL-10 signalling in macrophages is critical for the induction of CD206+ regulatory macrophages.
Anti-TNF therapy causes differentiation of macrophages to a more regulatory CD206+ phenotype.
IL-10 signalling in macrophages but not T cells was critical for the induction of CD206+ regulatory macrophages.
The therapeutic efficacy of anti-TNF in resolving intestinal inflammation is critically dependent on IL-10 signalling in macrophages.
